frontmatter.title: Embed & Include Content
frontmatter.description: You can embed labeled content (paragraphs, figures, notebook outputs, etc) across pages, allowing you to avoid re-writing the same information twice.
frontmatter.subject: MyST Markdown

children.value: (paragraphs, figures, notebook outputs, etc) across pages, allowing you to avoid re-writing the same information twice. You can also

If you have a labeled image in your documentation, you can embed it as a Figure so that it contains figure metadata (like a caption, or adding alt-text).
To do so, use a
For example, we‚Äôll define an image with a label below:
And embed it into a figure next with a new

```{figure} #nice-sunset
:label: sunset-figure
Here's a nice sunset with a caption!
```
Here‚Äôs a nice sunset with a caption!
The new label can be referred to in this context, i.e.

, which refers to the new figure rather than the original image. This allows you to scroll to embedded content on the page, rather than jumping to the original document. Note that this is especially useful with

You can include multiple files into your

document as if they were all written in the same file.
This allows you to store content in separate files, and then weave them together at build time.
To do so, use the

This is also helpful for including content snippets, such as a table or an equation, that you want to keep in a different file on disk, but present as if it were one document. In addition to Markdown,
for details about all the arguments you can give to
It is common practice to keep complex equations out of the main document so that they can be shared between slides, papers, and different renderings of a document. The
folder in our documentation has a

children.value: You will notice that there is no difference visually in the content, it is as if the content were include directly in line in the source document.
Relative Paths in Markdown vs LaTeX
of the include directive is the file path and is

to the file from which it was referenced. When working in markdown, recursive includes follow that same pattern. In LaTeX, however, recursive includes are relative to the original source file. This difference is only apparent when you have nested imports and a non-flat folder structure.
will also give you helpful warnings if it cannot find the file you are referencing.
By default the file will be parsed using
, you can also set the file to be
, which will show as a code-block; this is the same as using the
If you are working with the auto-reload (e.g.

), the file dependencies are auto-reloaded.
Circular dependencies are not allowed and
will issue a warning and not render the recursion.
Math and abbreviation frontmatter from included files
When including a file that has frontmatter, only some of that frontmatter is used. For example, the
are brought up to the top level and will overwrite any macros or abbreviations that already exist.
are shared in the same way that math macros are shared for markdown files.

parses source files (e.g. text files on your filesystem) and inserts them into the document structure as if you had written the content in your target source file. These files are not listed in your project table of contents, and generally only contain snippets.
content or outputs already parsed in your project.
